author: By Paul Frangipane
title: How a Babka Baron Spends His Sundays
description: Josh Russ Tupper checks in on the family business, Russ & Daughters. Then, it’s time for drinks and games with friends.
content: When Russ & Daughters, the renowned 107-year-old food counter business, opened an 18,000 square-foot shipping facility and factory in the Brooklyn Navy Yard three years ago, Josh Russ Tupper, one of the owners, was nervous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: Dutch-Turkish Novelist Depicts Her Journey to Secularism With No Inhibitions
description: Lale Gul’s autobiographical and sexually frank tale of a woman breaking with her conservative Muslim culture, and her strict parents, is a best seller in the Netherlands. “I’m done hiding,” she says.
content: AMSTERDAM — Perhaps naïvely, Lale Gul thought she could continue living with the same people on whom she had based her best-selling novel: her strict Turkish-Dutch migrant family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Delavan and Blaine Davis
title: In His Own Home, an Interior Stylist Takes a Light Touch
description: By filling his 1830s Brooklyn Heights apartment with just the essentials, Colin King has created an oasis of calm.
content: “I HAD LIVED HERE for a year but had never seen my apartment in the light of day until the Covid-19 pandemic,” says Colin King, a 33-year-old Brooklyn Heights-based interiors stylist. Before the stay-at-home orders went into effect in New York in March 2020, he’d spend his days running around to meetings with clients, or on his way to London, Copenhagen, Madrid or Marrakesh to produce design stories and advertisements for brands such as the Danish furniture company Hay and the American paint company Benjamin Moore. But it wasn’t until he was isolated in his 500-square-foot second-floor walk-up in front of an 1830s brownstone that King finally had time to think about what he wanted to do with his own space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: More isolated than ever, Afghanistan’s president clings to office.
description: President Ashraf Ghani, who has long refused to heed advice or delegate authority, now faces growing pressure to step aside ahead of the Taliban onslaught.
content: Several of his close political associates have surrendered to the Taliban without a fight, or fled into exile. His army has all but collapsed and the warlords he was counting on have proved ineffectual, or are bargaining for their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: C.D.C. Panel Recommends Third Dose of Covid Vaccine for Immunocompromised
description: A day after the F.D.A. authorized third doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines for some immunocompromised people, an independent expert panel advising the C.D.C. recommended the move.
content: WASHINGTON — An independent panel advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday recommended third doses of coronavirus vaccine for certain people with weakened immune systems, giving its support to the Food and Drug Administration’s authorization of the extra shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: When Some Rules Are Meant to Be Broken
description: Mary Devon Dietzen was reluctant to ever date anyone at work — until she met Lance McDonald almost four years ago.
content: Mary Devon Dietzen thought she knew everyone at the RAND Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., describing herself as a regular organizer of happy hours and other get-togethers with colleagues. But she didn’t know Lance McDonald until he walked into her meeting in October 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Chilled Dinners for Crazy-Hot Days
description: Silken tofu with tomatoes and peaches, caprese salad and more satisfying meals for the tail end of summer.
content: The dish I keep on repeat all summer long is something I’ve come to call the Super Caprese. It’s just a caprese salad, that ultra-Italian combination of fresh tomatoes, mozzarella, basil, salt and olive oil, but made deluxe and regarded as a complete meal, with olives and capers added, maybe prosciutto and salami, and a fair amount of bread on the side. If summer is here, so is the Super Caprese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Ed Shanahan
title: Lightning Strike at Bronx Beach Kills 13-Year-Old Boy
description: The teenager, Carlos Ramos, was one of at least seven people on Orchard Beach after lifeguards cleared the water with thunderstorms approaching on a blistering day, officials said.
content: Six days after celebrating his 13th birthday, a boy died Thursday night after he was struck by lightning in a fast-moving thunderstorm at Orchard Beach in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Flooding in China kills 21, as thousands escape to shelters.
description: Heavy rainfall, expected to continue through Friday night, brought flooding that drove more than 7,200 people into shelters and damaged property.
content: Flooding caused by torrential rain killed 21 people in China’s Hubei Province, officials said on Thursday, the latest deadly downpour in a summer of extreme weather that has killed hundreds of people across the country’s central region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: In the West, a Connection Between Covid and Wildfires
description: A new study links air pollution from wildfire smoke to higher rates of coronavirus cases and deaths.
content: Exposure to wildfire smoke during last summer’s wildfire season could be associated with thousands of additional coronavirus infections as well as hundreds of deaths, potentially causing an even greater challenge to public health officials in Washington, Oregon and California, a new study has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Fearing Kabul’s Fall, U.S. Officials Implore Afghans to ‘Fight’
description: The calls to action underscore the stark reality that the United States has no intention of rescuing government forces.
content: As the Afghan government lost control of more than a dozen cities in a matter of days, Biden administration officials repeatedly urged its collapsing security forces to demonstrate “leadership” and “will” to defend Kabul, their capital — underscoring the stark reality that the United States has no intention of rescuing them as the Taliban storm across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: A New Era for New York Times Newsletters
description: Introducing a new benefit for subscribers.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Johnson, Diana Nguyen, Chelsea Daniel, Paige Cowett, Rachel Quester and Chris Wood
title: A ‘Code Red for Humanity’
description: The climate emergency is here — and it will get worse before it could get better.
content: This show contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Who Will Take Care of America’s Caregivers?
description: Family caregivers contribute billions' worth of free labor to the economy each year. They need relief.
content: When you are old and gray and full of sleep and nodding by the fire — whom do you expect to help take care of you? Family? Friends? Paid aides? All of the above?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Lights! Camera! Action on New York’s Streets Again!
description: The pandemic shut down outdoor film shoots for months, but now the production trucks and crews are back and some New Yorkers are soaking it all in.
content: Ashley Psirogianes, a 26-year-old who works in fashion marketing, is a big “Sex and the City” fan. “I’ve been watching it a lot during lockdown,” she said. “I rewatched all the old episodes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Our Window of Climate Opportunity
description: To achieve a more “just and livable” future.
content: Welcome to Friday. In the weird time-warp that is this seemingly indefinite pandemic, we’re 1) as shocked as everyone it’s already mid-August and 2) sending our well-wishes to anyone with kids going back to school. If you have Covid-related questions about their return, record them in a voice memo and send them to us. We’ll answer them in an upcoming episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Who Knew Used Cars and Shipping Containers Would Matter So Much?
description: Economic notes from inside Plato’s Cave.
content: To be a good empirical economist, you must be prepared to make use of economic data without forgetting that the data is at best an imperfect guide to reality. I used to describe national income accounting — G.D.P. and all that — as a peculiarly boring form of science fiction. That’s not to say that the statisticians just make things up; they try really hard, and their work is immensely valuable. It’s just that any close look at how the numbers are constructed reveals that data coverage is always incomplete and the gaps are filled in with estimates and imputations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Dana Spiotta Talks About ‘Wayward’
description: Spiotta discusses her latest novel, and Ash Davidson talks about her debut, “Damnation Spring.”
content: In Dana Spiotta’s new novel, “Wayward,” a woman named Sam buys a dilapidated house in a neglected neighborhood in Syracuse, leaving her husband and her daughter in order to face down big midlife questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Whiplash for the Concert Business as the Delta Variant Rages On
description: Some tours and festivals are canceling, but others are forging ahead. As Covid-19 cases rise in the United States, artists weigh the risks and benefits of getting back on the road.
content: The concert industry had hoped that this summer would mark its high-decibel rebound after being shut down for more than a year by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amaali Lokuge
title: What It Will Take to Free Australia From the Bonds of Covid
description: An emergency room doctor in Melbourne shares her perspective
content: Almost half of Australia is in lockdown again as New South Wales loses control of the Delta variant and the virus leaks across porous borders. In Melbourne, the despair we feel at this current bout of isolation is almost overwhelming. We barely experienced life again before everything was canceled. It piques more because it comes at a time when high levels of immunity in some parts of the world are enabling a relaxing of restrictions that we, in Australia, can only dream about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: As Schools Prepare to Reopen Fully, Covid Safety Rules Are in Flux
description: Masks optional or enforced? Must adults be vaccinated? The biggest U.S. school districts are opening, but their policies vary widely, and some are adjusting them on the fly.
content: American schoolchildren are heading back to classrooms: All of the 100 largest districts in the country, including the biggest urban districts in every state, are fully reopening schools this fall, according to new data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: A Donor Makes a Long-Term Investment: In Mentoring Teens
description: A co-founder of Home Depot increased his giving for children in the pandemic because, he said, “they don’t always have the tools to deal with what’s happened to them.”
content: The wealthy in the United States have long made supporting colleges and universities one of their top priorities, and their money usually goes to projects like a new building, a scholarship fund or an endowment for a professorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How Identity Politics Took Over the Republican Party
description: The political scientist Lilliana Mason explains what exactly is polarizing us.
content: One problem with the conversation around political polarization is that it can imply that polarization is a static, singular thing. That our divisions are fixed and unchanging. But that’s not how it is at all. The dimensions of conflict change, and they change quickly. In the Obama era, Republicans mobilized against government spending and deficits but didn’t think much about election administration. Now, a trillion-dollar infrastructure package has passed the Senate with bipartisan support, but the divisions over democracy and voting access are deep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: French leaders call for vigilance amid vandalism at vaccine sites.
description: Officials say there have been 22 cases of vandalism at health sites since July 12, amid protests over the government’s Covid-19 health pass policy.
content: A vaccination center in southeastern France inundated with a fire hose, its walls vandalized with words equating vaccines with “genocide.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becca Foley
title: A Second Trip Into the Clouds to Remember
description: Rachel Basaldua and Dr. Howard Julien took a memorable trip on a hot-air balloon in Morocco. A few years later, he proposed on another balloon trip.
content: With a shared love of coffee and memories of sending pictures of bagels when they first started messaging, it’s fitting that Rachel Basaldua and Dr. Howard Julien met on the dating app Coffee Meets Bagel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: A Sicilian Town Sends an Omen of a Much Hotter Future
description: Floridia may have hit 124 degrees Fahrenheit this week, possibly the highest temperature ever recorded in Europe, offering Italy and the entire Mediterranean a preview of things to come.
content: FLORIDIA, Sicily — Before this week, the small Sicilian town of Floridia had a few claims to fame. The second wife of a Bourbon king was the town’s duchess. The snails that are a local delicacy are raised here. Its surrounding fields won it the greenest city in Italy prize in 2000. Its mayor is among Italy’s youngest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau Weighs Snap Election in Canada
description: The prime minister hopes his handling of the pandemic will help his Liberal Party win an early election. No decision has been made on the date.
content: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is considering dissolving Parliament, perhaps as soon as Sunday, to set Canada on a path for an election in late September. Such a move has been widely anticipated and would signal his confidence that voters will return him to power after three consecutive campaigns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Snopes Retracts 60 Articles Plagiarized by Co-Founder: ‘Our Staff Are Gutted’
description: The fact-checking site has banned David Mikkelson, who owns half the company, from writing articles after a BuzzFeed News investigation prompted an internal review.
content: Snopes, which has long presented itself as the internet’s premier fact-checking resource, has retracted 60 articles after a BuzzFeed News investigation found that the site’s co-founder plagiarized from news outlets as part of a strategy intended to scoop up web traffic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Nico Ali Walsh, a Grandson of Muhammad Ali, to Make Boxing Debut
description: It’s not clear how far boxing might take Ali Walsh. But his debut comes with the attention generated by his family name.
content: Nico Ali Walsh didn’t default to boxing, even though his grandfather, Muhammad Ali, was a three-time heavyweight champion and one of the best fighters in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Chasing Chopin’ and ‘V2’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: CHASING CHOPIN: A Musical Journey Across Three Centuries, Four Countries, and a Half-Dozen Revolutions, by Annik LaFarge. (Simon & Schuster, 240 pp., $17.) With the “Funeral March” at its center, LaFarge’s multifaceted “journey” covers everything from the tubercular composer’s relationship with the gender-bending author George Sand to the video game “Frederic: The Resurrection of Music.” “For a book about death,” Jeremy Denk wrote in his review, “it’s bursting with life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: The F.D.A. authorized a third dose of Covid vaccines for immunocompromised people.
description: The authorization applies to people who received solid organ transplants and others with similarly compromised immune systems.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday authorized third doses of Pfizer-BioNTech’s and Moderna’s coronavirus vaccines for some people with weakened immune systems, giving physicians more leeway to protect those who did not respond enough to an initial series of shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Oregon plans to send at least 500 National Guard troops to aid hospitals.
description: Gov. Kate Brown said that hospitals were at risk of becoming overwhelmed. She authorized as many as 1,500 troops to support health care workers.
content: Oregon will deploy at least 500 National Guard troops to help its hospitals deal with a flood of coronavirus patients, as the state faces the largest wave of infections it has seen during the pandemic, the state’s governor said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The Taliban seek to isolate Kabul, the Pentagon says.
description: Despite dwindling resistance to the Taliban advance, a Pentagon spokesman insisted that Afghan government forces could still fight back.
content: After a bracing string of battlefield victories, Taliban forces are seeking to isolate Kabul, the Pentagon said Friday, taking over border crossings, highways and lines of revenue on its march through Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: As the Taliban Advance in Afghanistan, Pressure on Pakistan Grows
description: The United States and others want Pakistan to push harder for peace. But many Pakistanis see a Taliban victory as inevitable, and some are cheering for one.
content: The Taliban are claiming towns and territories across Afghanistan. With each victory, scrutiny is falling on the leaders of neighboring Pakistan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Amid a Pandemic and Repression, a Boy Band Changes the Mood
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 13, 2021.
content: “Suddenly, they’ve realized that they could put down all these so-called big social things. There is something more joyful, playful, that draws them away from the political impasse of their youth.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Will That College Degree Pay Off?
description: A new report measures the “return on investment” offered by various higher education programs.
content: Most four-year degrees pay off by paving the way for graduates to recoup the cost of their education relatively quickly, a new analysis finds. But that’s particularly true for some programs, while others may offer little economic advantage over a high school diploma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Reach out and get in touch: a task force’s mission in Massachusetts.
description: Social isolation in the U.S. rose even as the pandemic began to subside in the spring, new research shows.
content: With the coronavirus attacking society at a molecular level, it has also exacerbated another epidemic that can be somewhat hidden: loneliness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Mount Vernon, N.Y.: Can Public Art Help to Heal Old Divisions?
description: A railroad trench split the city a century ago, but a new sculptural fence tells the local story from the Indigenous Siwanoy to the rapper Heavy D.
content: A diverse inner suburb just north of the Bronx, Mount Vernon, N.Y., has long been a city divided. But a site-specific new public sculpture has been installed in the middle of town with the ambition of helping to heal an old civic wound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia Says It Will Expel a BBC Journalist
description: The move, reported by a state television channel, comes amid an escalating confrontation with the Western news media and a crackdown on domestic dissent.
content: MOSCOW — Russia is expelling a BBC correspondent based in Moscow, Russian state television reported, the first time in years that a high-profile Western journalist has been publicly forced out of the country as part of a political dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Lilliana Mason
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Lilliana Mason. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Lilliana Mason. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: ‘Heels’ Is a Family Drama, With Body Slams
description: Like most wrestling shows, this Starz series suggests that the sport’s most compelling action happens outside of the ring.
content: Like many people, the actor Alexander Ludwig used to be a casual pro wrestling fan. Drifted away when he got older, as one does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Meet the Giraffe Weevil. It’s Got a Secret Up Its Long Snout.
description: The insect, found in New Zealand, has an evolutionary trick that supports its bizarre and elongated head.
content: The greatest jousting competitions in the world can be found on certain rotting trees in the New Zealand bush, where hordes of males compete for the opportunity to mate. The knights are not humans but New Zealand giraffe weevils, a species of beetle with a snout like a lance. The biggest males snout-wallop each other until the other either retreats or is knocked unceremoniously from the bark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Robert Plant and Alison Krauss Team Up Again, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Lizzo featuring Cardi B, Machine Gun Kelly, Brandee Younger and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: How Freelancing Is Changing Work
description: “When you talk to workers, they don’t want to sign up for a 9-to-5 job,” said Hayden Brown, who runs Upwork, a site that matches freelancers with employers.
content: Hayden Brown grew up with parents who were out to change the world. Her mother worked on women’s empowerment issues, and her father helped develop a national park in the Himalayas. For a time, the family lived in Nepal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: A Shape-Shifting Woman Plays All the Parts
description: Across three cities on bus shelters and a giant billboard, Martine Gutierrez, the artist, performer and provocateur, asks what it means to be a woman in these times.
content: A cast of goddesses, queens and other powerful women from across history and mythology are landing on 300 bus shelters in New York, Chicago and Boston. Co-opting the space of luxury perfume and fashion ads, 10 colossal photographic representations of feminine idols, conjured by a single name — Cleopatra, Aphrodite, Godiva, Sheba — gracefully bare themselves. What exactly are they selling?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Afghanistan, Booster Shots, Ice Cream: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google Infringed on Patents Owned by Sonos, a Trade Judge Says
description: Sonos is seeking to ban the import of several Google products that are made in China. The preliminary finding will now be reviewed by the full United States International Trade Commission.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google infringed on speaker-technology patents held by Sonos and should not be allowed to import products that violate Sonos’s intellectual property, a judge said in a preliminary finding by the United States International Trade Commission that was released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Janice Mirikitani, Poet and Crusader for People in Need, Dies at 80
description: Interned with her family during World War II, she became San Francisco’s poet laureate and an activist on behalf of the city’s marginalized people.
content: Janice Mirikitani, a vibrant former poet laureate of San Francisco who spent time as a child in an internment camp for people of Japanese ancestry during World War II, then worked most of her life aiding people in need, died on July 29 in a hospital in San Francisco. She was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: C.E.O.s Play Follow the Leader
description: On vaccine mandates, there is safety in numbers.
content: As they approach the limits of persuasion and incentives, the biggest question facing companies is whether to make coronavirus vaccines mandatory for workers. This is legally allowed, but many companies are still worried about political implications, employee pushback and other issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alysia Santo and R.G. Dunlop
title: Where Police Killings Often Meet With Silence: Rural America
description: As fatal police shootings have become a flashpoint in U.S. cities, they have also occurred at high rates in rural areas — largely without national attention.
content: PIPPA PASSES, Ky. — The man known all his life as Doughboy had been running from the state police for months: scrambling down a creek bed, flooring it out of a gas station, visiting his children at 2 a.m. when he thought troopers wouldn’t be lurking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Why an Ex-Supermodel Who Says She Was Raped at 17 Is Suing Now
description: Carré Sutton accuses a former executive at a modeling agency of sexual assault, and a second employee of enabling the attacks.
content: In the early 1980s, long before she would become one of the most recognizable models in the world, Carré Otis was living miserably in Northern California. Her parents had split up and her family was deeply unhappy; she was dyslexic and struggling in school. At 16, she ran away and lived on the streets. “It was my only hope,” she told me recently, from her home in Colorado, where she has settled into a quiet life with her husband and children, “that I could make it in modeling.’’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Joys of Parks During a Pandemic
description: Public parks are a lifeline, especially now. Plus, San Francisco will require vaccination for indoor dining, gyms and theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Geometric Faucets That Prize Form and Function
description: These stylish spigots come in a playful array of finishes, from colorful powder coats to mixed metals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Maybe Don’t Trust an Online Quiz With Your Personal Life
description: Katie Heaney used to take multiple-choice quizzes to determine whether she was gay or straight. Turns out, she had the answers all along.
content: In her 2018 Modern Love essay “Am I Gay or Straight? Maybe This Fun Quiz Will Tell Me,” the writer Katie Heaney describes how her love of multiple-choice quizzes, which had provided a “lifelong source of support and comfort,” hindered her ability to trust herself — even when it came to her sexuality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Week 10: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 20 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 31.
content: Welcome to Week 10, the final week of our 12th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Times Readers on the Most Significant Works of Postwar Architecture
description: An incomplete smattering of commenters’ takes on the buildings that should have made our list.
content: When T assembled a panel of architects, designers and journalists to create a list of the 25 Most Significant Works of Postwar Architecture, we knew going into it that Times readers would have their own ideas about buildings that ought to have been included or omitted; even our jury members were cognizant of the inherent limitations of such an assignment. With that in mind, here are some more significant buildings erected since World War II, chosen based on a smattering of the wealth of comments we received on Instagram and on the original article itself, where many people rallied for the world’s most famous starchitects — where’s Frank Gehry? Zaha Hadid? Frank Lloyd Wright? I.M. Pei? — and others made passionate pleas for lesser-known works that personally moved them. Some of the below had been discussed (and discarded) during our original conversation; all are worth a closer look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ryder Howe
title: The Cutthroat World of $10 Ice Cream
description: Small scoop shops fueled the innovation that made frozen treats a hot market. What happens to indie favorites in the golden age of the freezer aisle?
content: Put the ice cream near the cash registers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Tariro Mzezewa and Giulia Heyward
title: Behind the Surprising Jump in Multiracial Americans, Several Theories
description: Families across the country have grown more diverse. A design change in the census form also allowed the government to report people’s identity in greater detail.
content: WASHINGTON — The Census Bureau released a surprising finding this week: The number of non-Hispanic Americans who identify as multiracial had jumped by 127 percent over the decade. For people who identified as Hispanic, the increase was even higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: They Might Claim That Things Are Fixed
description: Would you buy a used car from John Guzzetta and Michael Hawkins? How about a brain-buster of a puzzle?
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes a themeless is just seamless, but to make it so usually requires first a “seed” entry (or several) to anchor it, then loads of effort, a lot of painful tearing apart, more work, some time to ripen, further labors, and then some burnishing. And that’s before any editors get their hands on it. When a themeless puzzle is a collaboration, the process may be even more protracted as it is swapped back and forth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Los Angeles and Chicago schools to mandate teacher vaccinations.
description: The two systems have announced some of the strongest vaccine requirements to date, which could put pressure on other cities, like New York.
content: As schools prepare to reopen five days per week amid an alarming surge in the coronavirus, Los Angeles and Chicago, the second and third-largest districts in the nation, announced on Friday some of the strongest teacher vaccine mandates to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devi Lockwood
title: What Does It Mean for a Whole Nation to Become Uninhabitable?
description: “It’s changing quite rapidly,” says a hunter in Canada. “And I’m not old at all. I’m 31.”
content: Devi Lockwood spent five years traveling the globe talking to people about changes they were seeing to their local water and climates. Here are some of the stories she heard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gavin Edwards
title: Nanci Griffith, Singer Who Blended Folk and Country, Dies at 68
description: Her best-loved songs were closely observed tales of small-town life, sometimes with painful details in the lyrics, but typically sung with a deceptive prettiness.
content: Nanci Griffith, a Grammy-winning singer and songwriter who kept one foot in folk and the other in country and was blessed with a soaring voice equally at home in both genres, died on Friday. She was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: The 40-Hour Work Week Is, in Fact, Life
description: There is no magical way to earn a full-time salary without working full-time.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Making it Official After Nearly Three Decades Together
description: Political turmoil and the pandemic pushed Eric Ostrow and Scott Linder to finally get married.
content: If not for the political turmoil of the last few years, Eric Ostrow and Scott Linder would probably not be planning to celebrate their 28th anniversary in December as a newly married couple. “I always used to tease Eric: We’ll just be like Kurt Russell and Goldie Hawn — no need to get married,” Mr. Linder said. But the threat they felt was strong enough that they decided to reconsider their position. “The past four years were terrifying for us,” said Mr. Ostrow, the director of client services at the law firm Harmon Linder & Rogowsky in New York. “I did not feel safe as a gay man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Extreme temperatures continue to envelop the U.S., but some relief is in sight.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, storms and more.
content: If the forecasters are right, the extreme heat that has scorched much of the United States this week is now, thankfully, on its way out in hard-hit places like the Northeast and the Pacific Northwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gao
title: Jared Padalecki on the ‘Walker’ Finale and ‘Supernatural’
description: In an interview, the actor and producer talks about the season finale’s big twist and the “Supernatural” prequel that took him by surprise.
content: This interview contains spoilers for Thursday’s season finale of “Walker.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharif Hassan
title: An Afghan warlord who steadfastly resisted the Taliban surrendered. Others may follow his lead.
description: The surrender of Ismail Khan, the only warlord who posed a serious threat to the insurgents in the western region of the country, could be a sign that others may soon switch allegiances.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A prominent Afghan warlord and former governor, who had resisted Taliban attacks in western Afghanistan for weeks and rallied many to his cause to push back the insurgent offensive, surrendered on Friday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asmaa al-Omar and Ben Hubbard
title: For a Crime at 14, He Faces Death in a Case Casting Doubt on Saudi Reforms
description: The kingdom has announced changes to its justice system, but still sentenced a teenager to death for a robbery and the killing of a police officer, despite an alibi and claims of a forced confession.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The thief entered the jewelry store disguised as a woman, in a black gown and face veil, then drew a pistol and an assault rifle to rob the place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Will No Longer Face Impeachment, Assembly Leader Says
description: Carl Heastie, the speaker of the New York State Assembly, said the body would end its investigation of Gov. Andrew Cuomo when his resignation takes effect later this month.
content: The leader of the New York State Assembly said Friday that lawmakers will suspend their ongoing impeachment investigation of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, following his resignation earlier this week over sexual harassment allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: 6 Ways to Tame Airline Nightmares
description: Thousands of passengers have experienced delayed or canceled flights since June when airlines began to struggle with surging demand and worker shortages. Here’s how to deal with the chaos.
content: Camille Walker’s troubles with Southwest Airlines began well before her trip to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in July when her direct flight from Louisville, Ky., was changed to a connecting flight through Atlanta. It became a nightmare when she tried to return from vacation and her departure was pushed back 24 hours. The flight boarded, only to sit on the runway for hours. Assuming she’d miss her connection, Ms. Walker, who works in marketing, found a Delta Air Lines flight she could connect to, but a flight attendant said many passengers were making connections and that the airline would take care of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Donald Kagan, Leading Historian of Ancient Greece, Dies at 89
description: His studies of the Peloponnesian War and his impassioned teaching style inspired generations of scholars, as well as Washington strategists.
content: Donald Kagan, a Yale historian whose impassioned teaching and writing about the ancient Greeks inspired generations of scholars as well as Washington strategists, including many of the officials who crafted American foreign policy under Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush, died on Aug. 6 at a retirement home in Washington. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadef Ali Kully and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Adams Pledges Support for Gowanus Redevelopment, Boosting Delayed Project
description: Eric Adams said he would support one of the signature development plans of Mayor Bill de Blasio, as long as spending to repair public housing is included.
content: A long-delayed development project that would transform the banks of Brooklyn’s notoriously filthy Gowanus Canal into the home of thousands of new apartments and scores of shops appears poised to move forward under a new mayor — as long as nearby public housing developments also receive hundreds of millions of dollars for repairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: How Fermented Foods May Alter Your Microbiome and Improve Your Health
description: Foods like yogurt, kimchi, sauerkraut and kombucha increased the diversity of gut microbes and led to lower levels of inflammation.
content: Fermented foods like yogurt, kimchi, sauerkraut and kombucha have long been dietary staples in many parts of the world. Indeed, for thousands of years, different cultures relied on fermentation to produce bread and cheese, preserve meats and vegetables, and enhance the flavors and textures of many foods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Season 2 Episode 4 Recap: A Very Special Christmas Episode
description: It’s only a matter of time before the poster-board and markers come out …
content: Houston? We have a Christmas Episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: Leos Carax on ‘Annette’ and the Cinema of Doubt
description: His movies often arrive amid a commotion, and his newest is no exception: “If you’re going to make a musical, you’ve got to be either ambitious or pretentious.”
content: Leos Carax, the enigmatic French director behind spectacularly peculiar films like “Holy Motors,” would rather be talking about love. Or beauty. Or ghosts. Anything other than his new musical melodrama, “Annette.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Possible Election Call as the Pandemic’s 4th Wave Gets Underway
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau may call an early election as soon as Sunday despite rising Covid-19 cases. If so, it won’t be campaigning as usual.
content: The country may, or may not, be headed into an election at the same time that a fourth Covid-19 surge is now underway thanks to the Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner and Johnny Milano
title: In a Field in Iowa, the White Sox Delivered a Hollywood Ending
description: M.L.B.’s “Field of Dreams” game was packed full of nostalgia, but Tim Anderson’s walk-off homer made sure this sequel-of-sorts created memories of its own.
content: DYERSVILLE, Iowa — Their movie never felt like a surefire hit, not exactly. But what the caretakers of “Field of Dreams” have always had is a sense of duty, as if they were stewards of something precious. Kevin Costner felt that way when filming it here 33 years ago, and he felt it again before the live sequel, of sorts, on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Jones
title: What Did He Think of Our Night Together?
description: Four years ago, Andrew Rannells published his side of a hookup gone wrong in Modern Love. Now, as a director, he explores the same story from both characters’ perspectives.
content: In his 2017 Modern Love essay, “During a Night of Casual Sex, Urgent Messages Go Unanswered,” the writer, actor and director Andrew Rannells recounts a second date that took a tragic turn when he learned that his father had collapsed and was in a coma. He died a few days later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Stream These Five Action Films Now
description: In our sights this month: a vengeful assassin, giant killer moths, a Russian Batman, punk gladiators and, well, a crazed pastor we can’t even begin to explain.
content: For action fans seeking out new movies on streaming, there are plenty of car chases, explosions and fist fights to sift through. We help by providing some streaming highlights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: House Moderates Say They Won’t Back Budget Vote Until Infrastructure Bill Passes
description: The letter from nine Democrats, enough to block passage, threatens their party’s two-track plan to pass both a $3.5 trillion social policy budget blueprint and an infrastructure bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Nine moderate House Democrats told Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday that they will not vote for a budget resolution meant to pave the way for the passage of a $3.5 trillion social policy package later this year until a Senate-approved infrastructure bill passes the House and is signed into law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Depth Won the Premier League. The Next Step Will Cost More.
description: Manchester City’s winning formula has delivered trophies. But to win the Champions League, it may need to make a few expensive changes.
content: All these years on, it is hard to identify the exact straw that broke the camel’s back. Perhaps it was the night when Carlos Tévez, in the thick of a Champions League game against Bayern Munich, seemed to refuse to come on as a substitute. Maybe it was the evening Mario Balotelli spent setting off fireworks in, and setting fire to, his own bathroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Sergio Olmos
title: The Pacific Northwest, Built for Mild Summers, Is Scorching Yet Again
description: Punishing heat has left hundreds dead as it buckles roads and strains bridges. Cities are exploring how to adjust for a warming climate.
content: SEATTLE — Road crews sprayed water on century-old bridges in Seattle on Thursday to keep the steel from expanding in the sizzling heat. In Portland, Ore., where heat has already killed dozens of people this summer, volunteers delivered water door to door. Restaurants and even some ice cream shops decided it was too hot to open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Robin Pogrebin
title: A Gallery Sells Hunter Bidens. The White House Says It Won’t Know Who’s Buying.
description: Hunter Biden’s works are being offered for as much as $500,000 apiece; his art dealer said he would follow ethics guidelines that the Biden administration helped to develop.
content: The Georges Bergès Gallery has sat on a chic stretch of SoHo for six years now, a relatively little-known newcomer in a New York art world that has long been dominated by name-brand power brokers like Pace Gallery and Gagosian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Experts and readers weigh in on the future of remote work.
content: When the pandemic is in the rearview mirror — some day — many of us may look back on these years as the moment that our work lives changed forever. When millions of employees were told to work remotely, the boundary between our office lives and home lives began to blur, in ways that are still unfolding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A Music Festival Wedding with Two Grooms as the Main Event
description: Jamon Deaver and Joey Lawton created a weekend-long celebration for their wedding in the wilds outside of Berea, Ky.
content: The wedding of Jamon Deaver and Joey Lawton can best be described as a camping trip, music festival and immersive art show all rolled into one long weekend in the wilds outside of Berea, Ky. Big city fun meets country living; summer camp mixed with Bonnaroo and Coachella; one epic wedding weekend filled with love and wonderment, the invitation promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Judge Permits Biden’s Replacement Evictions Ban to Stay in Place for Now
description: But the judge said she doubted the Supreme Court would ultimately find it lawful.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Friday permitted the Biden administration’s replacement evictions moratorium to continue, saying that she lacked authority to block such an emergency public-health policy even though she believed “the government is unlikely to prevail” when the matter returns to the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran’s Health System ‘Beyond Disastrous’ from Covid Surge
description: The Delta variant of the coronavirus has overwhelmed the country, which has been reeling from the pandemic since it began, presenting a stark test for its new hard-line president.
content: Hospital medics in Iran are triaging patients on the floors of emergency rooms and in cars parked on the roadside. Lines stretch for blocks outside pharmacies. Taxis double as hearses, transporting corpses from hospitals to cemeteries. In at least one city, laborers are digging mass graves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: A Changing Country
description: The United States population is getting more diverse, according to data from the 2020 census.
content: The United States population is getting more diverse, according to new data from the 2020 census that offers a once-in-a-decade look at the makeup of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J.S. Marcus
title: Jan Lisiecki, Piano’s Doogie Howser, Comes of Age With Chopin
description: For this rising artist, Chopin’s 21 nocturnes are “pieces I play for myself.” A new recording will bring them to an audience.
content: The Canadian pianist Jan Lisiecki started out as something of the Doogie Howser of classical music. He was signed by the august record label Deutsche Grammophon when he was just 15, and at 18 was named an unusually young Young Artist of the Year by Gramophone magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Afghanistan’s Unraveling May Strike Another Blow to U.S. Credibility
description: Allies may understand the desire to give up on a failed project, but the retreat heightens the sense that America’s backing is no longer unbounded.
content: BRUSSELS — Afghanistan’s rapid unraveling is already raising grumblings about American credibility, compounding the wounds of the Trump years and reinforcing the idea that America’s backing for its allies is not unlimited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eyal Press
title: America Runs on ‘Dirty Work’
description: Morally compromising jobs, like material resources, are not distributed equally.
content: After the recession in 2008, Harriet Krzykowski was hired as a mental health aide at the Dade Correctional Institution, a prison in South Florida. Her salary was modest — $12 an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Census Shows a Nation That Resembles Its Future More Than Its Past
description: For Democrats, there was much to cheer in the growth of cities and suburbs. But Republicans, imperiled by the falling white population, are still well positioned for redistricting.
content: At first blush, Thursday’s release of census data held great news for Democrats. It painted a portrait of a considerably more urban and metropolitan nation, with increasingly Democratic metropolitan areas bustling with new arrivals and the rural, Republican heartland steadily losing residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Kurzweil
title: When a Fictional Utopia Offers a Pathway Home
description: Reading Ursula K. Le Guin’s “Always Coming Home” after a cross country move to California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: Overheated Real Estate Market Begins to Cool
description: Supercharged by tight inventory and pent-up demand, home prices continued to rise in July, but at a slower rate.
content: The pandemic created a frenzied real estate market in much of the United States that has yet to let up, with demand for housing still outpacing the number of homes coming on the market, giving sellers a heavy upper hand in most of the country. But economists say the market cooled off a bit in July — perhaps a sign that the wild price appreciations of the past year may have scared off some buyers who prefer to wait until things calm down, to stay put or to continue renting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Local officials struggled with eviction freeze as cases stacked up.
description: Inside a Las Vegas courtroom last week, renters and landlords battled over evictions that continued at a brisk pace despite a last-minute, two-month extension of the federal protections meant to keep people in their homes.
content: Inside a Las Vegas courtroom last week, renters and landlords battled over evictions that continued at a brisk pace despite a last-minute, two-month extension of the federal protections meant to keep people in their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Boeing’s Starliner Launch Is Delayed, Again, Possibly Until Next Year
description: Problems with the capsule’s propulsion system require more troubleshooting, a setback for a program to carry NASA astronauts to the space station.
content: Boeing’s Starliner spacecraft has been recalled to the factory because of sticky valves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Vaccination Rates in N.Y.C., and One Major Disparity
description: Only 28 percent of Black New Yorkers ages 18 to 44  are fully vaccinated — a number that worries health experts as the Delta variant spreads.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Spy in the Family and Our Hotter Future: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Floods devastate northern Turkey, killing at least 27 and leaving dozens missing.
description: In one small town, eight members of an extended family were missing after a building collapse, including four children.
content: Flash floods in northern Turkey have killed at least 27 people, and left many other local residents missing and hundreds homeless, as rescue workers scrambled to evacuate those affected by the disaster and reach villages that had been cut off by the waters and lost power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Bad News for ‘Trump-Adjacent Weirdos’ Delights Seth Meyers
description: Meyers enjoyed seeing Mike Lindell get word on camera that a defamation suit against him over his claims of election fraud would proceed.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton DiSclafani
title: The Vaccine Refusers Are Testing My Love of the South
description: I like living in a place where not everyone thinks the same way I do. Or at least I used to.
content: AUBURN, Ala. — When I had just moved here — six years ago and a lifetime ago — I was shopping at Publix, wheeling my cart out to the car. My baby sat in the buggy. I hit a bump, and the bottle of sparkling water I’d just bought skittered onto the ground, exploding. A young man in a Publix uniform ran up; I anticipated frustration (I’d made quite a mess), but instead he apologized for my mistake and ran inside to get another bottle to replace it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: After Matching on Words With Friends, a ‘Match of My Life’
description: Nirmala Dewi and David Gracey met three years ago while playing the online word generator game.
content: Three years ago, David Gracey was going through the breakup of his marriage of 25 years. He still lived with one of his two children and his two dogs, but found himself with more alone time now. Whenever he had a free moment, he would pass the time by playing Words with Friends, a multiplayer online game similar to Scrabble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Where Dark Skies Draw Star-Gazers, Wildfire Smoke Spoils the View
description: Parts of the Mountain West still largely free of light pollution or cloudy weather are losing their famed spectacular views of the night sky to smoke from fires burning hundreds of miles upwind.
content: GREAT SAND DUNES NATIONAL PARK — The high, lonesome dunes that run up against the Rocky Mountains at 7,500 feet above sea level in southern Colorado are a long, long drive from the closest streetlight, and after dusk, the almost untainted darkness and thin, dry air reveals just how bright the night sky can actually be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Stuck in Different Time Zones While Living Two Subway Stops Apart
description: Amanda Gefter had few issues with her nocturnal life — until she fell in love with someone who kept more conventional hours.
content: In her 2016 Modern Love essay “The Night Girl Finds a Day Boy,” the writer Amanda Gefter explains what it is like to live — and date — with delayed sleep phase syndrome, a circadian rhythm disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: The Real Stories Behind the New Season of ‘Modern Love’
description: And: Pandemic pods are back.
content: “This might be the start of Kit Harington’s romantic comedy career,” Daniel Jones, the editor of Modern Love, said to me recently, only half joking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart, Michael Gold, Anna Martin, Hans Buetow, Theo Balcomb, Phyllis Fletcher and Corey Schreppel
title: Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez are Back Together, and We Can’t Look Away
description: The internet’s obsession with Bennifer may tell us more about ourselves than about the superstar couple.
content: Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck first started dating in 2002, then broke up after a brief engagement. This summer found both celebrities newly (and briefly) single, and — as photos of kisses at restaurants, on yachts and on J. Lo’s own Instagram confirmed — passionately reunited. “Bennifer” is yet again the portmanteau of the moment. They’re the couple of the summer. And the internet can’t get enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Bobby Shmurda’s New Lust for Life
description: The Brooklyn rapper, fresh off nearly seven years in prison on gang conspiracy charges, is plotting his dance-heavy comeback — slowly.
content: Bobby Shmurda just can’t sit still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Alanis Thames
title: Forget Friday Night Lights: High School Stars Seek a Better Deal
description: With college athletes now allowed to profit from their name, image and likeness, high school athletes are also looking to cash in.
content: Quarterback Quinn Ewers of Southlake, Texas, was expected to lead his city’s storied high school team this fall in its quest for another state championship as the nation’s top football prospect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Sharif Hassan
title: The Afghan Military Was Built Over 20 Years. How Did It Collapse So Quickly?
description: The Taliban’s rapid advance has made clear that U.S. efforts to turn Afghanistan’s military into a robust, independent fighting force have failed, with its soldiers feeling abandoned by inept leaders.
content: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The surrenders seem to be happening as fast as the Taliban can travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Christina Goldbaum
title: Three more major cities are under Taliban control, as the government’s forces near collapse.
description: With Lashkar Gah and Kandahar, the Taliban now effectively control southern Afghanistan. The western city of Herat is also in their hands.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three major cities in western and southern Afghanistan were confirmed on Friday to have fallen to the Taliban, as the insurgents’ race to take control of the country accelerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: If You Skip the Vaccine, It Is My ‘Damn Business’
description: Wearing a helmet while bike riding, strapping on your seatbelt in a car — these are personal decisions. Vaccination is different.
content: When asked if he had gotten a Covid-19 vaccine, Lamar Jackson, a quarterback for the Baltimore Ravens, declined to answer. “I feel it’s a personal decision,” he said. “I’m just going to keep my feelings to my family and myself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The results of the U.S. census.
content: America has grown far more diverse in the past decade with a surge in Hispanic and Asian populations, according to the Census Bureau. The non-Hispanic white population declined to 58 percent of the population, down from 64 percent in 2010. Overall population growth also slowed substantially.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Nicki Minaj and Husband Sued, Accused of Harassing Sexual Assault Victim
description: Jennifer Hough said in a lawsuit filed in New York that the couple pressured her to recant her account of the rapper’s husband, Kenneth Petty, sexually assaulting her in 1994.
content: A woman who accused the rapper Nicki Minaj’s husband, Kenneth Petty, of sexual assault during high school filed a lawsuit on Friday against the couple, alleging that they harassed and intimidated her while trying to convince her to recant her account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Jones
title: Stepping Forward Into Marriage, Round Two
description: When Mary Elizabeth Williams got back together with her husband, she didn’t expect a cancer diagnosis — or for her story to inspire a television episode.
content: In her 2014 Modern Love essay, “A Second Embrace, With Hearts and Eyes Open,” the writer Mary Elizabeth Williams tells the story of rekindling her marriage only to find out, shortly thereafter, that she had malignant melanoma. Suddenly, their future looked very different from their past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Drew Vickers and Suzanne Koller
title: Bold Patterns to Wear When You Re-enter the World
description: This season, step out in glittering fabrics, striking silhouettes and whimsical textures made with celebration in mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Messner
title: School Newspaper Editor Bears Witness
description: In Tim Lockette’s “Tell It True,” a budding journalist in a small Alabama town reports on capital punishment.
content: TELL IT TRUEBy Tim Lockette
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Latest U.K. Scandals Show a System Rife With Insider Ties
description: For years, Britain relied on an informal code of gentlemen’s agreements to help prevent influence-peddling and cronyism in politics. Some say that no longer works.
content: LONDON — A multimillion-dollar payday for a former British prime minister. A secretive group of wealthy donors with special access to top politicians. A party fund-raiser with close connections not just to Prime Minister Boris Johnson, but also to Britain’s royal family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: Amid Extreme Weather, a Shift Among Republicans on Climate Change
description: Many Republicans in Congress no longer deny that Earth is heating because of fossil fuel emissions. But they say abandoning oil, gas and coal will harm the economy.
content: WASHINGTON — After a decade of disputing the existence of climate change, many leading Republicans are shifting their posture amid deadly heat waves, devastating drought and ferocious wildfires that have bludgeoned their districts and unnerved their constituents back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Benjamin
title: Genial and Respectful? Why New York’s Next Governor Is a Radical
description: She’s spent most of her career out of the spotlight, but she is a canny and adaptable political operator.
content: Kathy Hochul, on the cusp of becoming New York’s first woman governor, has been consigned to a strange limbo for the next 12 days because of Andrew Cuomo’s time-delayed resignation — a lag she has made clear is not her preference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: When a Social Butterfly Meets a Homebody
description: After meeting Aaron Goldstein two years ago, Arielle Patrick says she has a greater appreciation for the quiet nights spent at home.
content: There was a time in Arielle Patrick’s life when her refrigerator was nearly empty and her social calendar completely full.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons
title: 12 Years, $800 Million, One Conviction: Lebanon Tribunal Winds Down Short of Answers
description: Established in 2009 to prosecute those responsible for the assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, the tribunal failed to show who ordered the attack or why.
content: In a nation where the poor struggle to buy food, and electricity is scarce, medicine in short supply and corruption rife, the crimes of the past have a hard time competing with the suffering of the present.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri, Joseph Goldstein, Winnie Hu, Patrick McGeehan, Eliza Shapiro and Annie Correal
title: 6 Issues Kathy Hochul Will Face as New York Governor
description: Ms. Hochul is preparing to become New York’s next governor at a precarious time for the state, as it faces challenges in public health, housing, education and infrastructure.
content: In less than two weeks, Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul will become the next governor of New York, amid a period of exceptional tumult and uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Wedding Business Is Booming, a Short-Term Jolt to the Economy
description: Frantic caterers, $200,000 weekends: The wedding industry is on fire, bringing spending, and bottlenecks.
content: Meg Van Dyke, who runs a Pittsburgh wedding planning company, spent a recent weeknight frantically calling photographers for a May 2022 wedding. All eight who fit her couple’s criteria were fully booked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Clumsy Moves on the Dance Floor Lead to Romance
description: Sara Saxner and Daniel Coughlin met at a bar in January. “We literally backed into each other dancing to ‘Baby Got Back,’” Ms. Saxner said.
content: Sara Saxner and Daniel Coughlin met by pure accident in January 2017. “We literally backed into each other dancing to ‘Baby Got Back’ at our local Virginia-Highlands bar, Dark Horse,” Ms. Saxner said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Black Athletes Should Leave White Colleges
description: They attract money and attention to the predominantly white universities that showcase them, while H.B.C.U.s struggle. What would happen if they collectively decided to go to black schools?
content: They attract money and attention to the predominantly white universities that showcase them, while H.B.C.U.s struggle. What would happen if they collectively decided to go to black schools?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Photographer Fighting Visual Clichés of Africa
description: Aïda Muluneh’s vibrant images explore Ethiopian identity, and her photo festival aspires to shape a new vision of the continent.
content: Aïda Muluneh’s vibrant images explore Ethiopian identity, and her photo festival aspires to shape a new vision of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

title: People Who Pay People to Kill People
description: The twisted logic behind hiring a hit man.
content: The twisted logic behind hiring a hit man.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Newsletters have a history even longer than newspapers, and email is several decades older than the web. content: Good morning. Eric Kim is in The New York Times Magazine this week with a lovely paean to affogato, that delightful modern Italian dessert of gelato drowned by a shot of espresso. “The magic of an affogato is that even a bad one can be very good,” he writes, “but a very good one can change your life.”
